4.text:
My name is Rebecca Adlington, I'm an Olympic
swimmer. I've been swimming

9.text:
since I was 8 or 9, when I was younger I wasn't
able to drive myself to training.

15.text:
The biggest thing for me was that mum and
dad gave up so much time to take

19.text:
me, with really early starts, having to get
up at 5 in the morning. Mum decided to

25.text:
give up her job for me and dedicate all her
time to taking me training. As soon as

30.text:
I could drive, mum so relieved, she was like
'You'd better pass your test!' They

38.text:
still help me out now, even though I’m 21.
My mum comes over and cooks a

43.text:
meal for me every now and again. They’re
always there, every single competition

47.text: I go to they are there cheering me on.

53.text:
I've never pressed snooze in my life, I've
never not gone training. Everyone

57.text:
always thinks that's bizarre, but it's because
I love it so much. It has turned into

61.text:
more of a job now because I don't really do
anything else, I don't study or

65.text:
anything. I just love doing it, so to me it
is still a hobby.

71.text:
Because we burn off so much, we eat so much
more than everyone else. If I'm

78.text:
having a meal with everyone else, I eat double
what everyone else does.

82.text:
Obviously we don't eat takeaways. I just balance
it out, I don’t eat any fish,

90.text:
people always think it's good for you, but
it's just what you like and don’t like,

95.text:
just
try and stay away from takeaways. I do treat

101.text: myself to chocolate now and again.

105.text:
Me and Jo are such good friends, people think
that's so weird, but we're so close

111.text:
because we spend so much time together, because
we do the same event.

114.text:
Because we have that, it makes us even better
friends. We always support each

119.text:
other, no matter what. If I'm not on the podium,
I want Jo to be there, I'd support

123.text:
her all the way. It is individual, as soon
as you dive in the pool, you do it for

130.text:
yourself. You're in your own lane, you've
got to give it all you have. I'm always

135.text:
going to want to win, no matter who it's against.
I'd always want, if I'm not there,

139.text:
for Joe to be there. I'd love to see a British
girl on the podium if it wasn’t me.

142.text:
The team have become like a family now. We're
so close, we see each other all

148.text:
the time outside of swimming. It's good because
we train Saturday morning then

152.text:
get the rest of the weekend off, which is
so nice. You get to go shopping, see

157.text:
your friends and family at the weekends, and
do something on a Saturday night.

160.text:
We are all so close, we do stuff together
now.

168.text:
I’m so competitive in everything, I get
so angry at Christmas if we're playing a

175.text:
quiz. If my family don't don’t take it seriously
and I don't win. I'm not a sore

181.text:
looser, I just love competing, love getting
involved in the race, whether I'm out in

188.text:
front, or I'm winning or loosing, I love the
whole race environment, the whole

191.text:
nerves, being so focussed, so satisfying when
you finish, and all the hard work

199.text: has paid off. It's such a great feeling.

202.text:
I’m so nervous before a race, it's unbelievable.
Before the 800 in Beijing, I was

212.text:
feeling sick, I thought I was going to cry,
I had to lay down, just going from one

218.text:
extreme to another. I thought I was going
to faint, I was in tears, I was an

223.text:
emotional wreck. My coach said it's just your
body getting ready to race. Every

228.text:
single time I still get so nervous, I just
feel sick or I'm going to pass out or

235.text:
something! It's that adrenalin rush that you
get, and you're so focussed as well.

240.text:
Some people like to listen to music, but I
just can't, I like to concentrate, I like

243.text:
to
think of everything I've done in training,

246.text:
past experiences where I've been
working so hard, everything my coach has told

251.text:
me, I go through in my head and
really like to fully focus and just not get

261.text:
The first race happened, in the 400 and half
way through the race, I wasn't

265.text:
actually anywhere near winning, then something
happened, and I just went for it.

272.text:
When I was coming in, I honestly thought I'd
come second, and didn't think I'd got

276.text:
the gold at all, and then turning around and
seeing the score board, was

280.text:
unbelievable and then seeing that Jo got a
medal as well. We were so happy, we

285.text:
were hugging and crying together, it was brilliant.
I didn't expect it at all. It was so

292.text:
overwhelming, the media and everything afterwards.
I then had to race again in

298.text:
the 800, I just had to keep it quiet, we went
out to a different location, didn't train

304.text:
in the Cube again, and tried not to get sucked
into the atmosphere. And then the

308.text:
800 happened, and I enjoyed the whole experience,
I was then cheerleader for

313.text:
everyone afterwards, it was so good, such
a good week.

317.text:
As much as I'll remember Beijing for the rest
of my life, you put it in the past, I've

324.text:
learnt from it, a new competition is just
a new competition, you have to treat it so

329.text:
differently. That's what I've done since.
It's so exciting now with London coming

334.text:
up, now all the fans will be cheering for
us and not the Americans or somebody

339.text:
else, hopefully they will be cheering for
us! Just to be there will be absolutely
